structured_info.title_cn: IEEE 802.11bd与IEEE 802.11p在动态交通场景下数据传播特性的比较研究
structured_info.title_en: A Comparative Study of IEEE 802.11bd and IEEE 802.11p on the Data Dissemination Properties in Dynamic Traffic Scenarios
structured_info.abstract: With the rapid deployment of intelligent transportation systems in real-life applications, both dedicated short-range communications (DSRC) and cellular Vehicle-to-Everything (C-V2X), utilized to enable V2X communication, are undergoing extensive development to meet the quality of service (QoS) demands of advanced vehicular applications and scenarios. Compared to C-V2X, which lacks fully validated effective reliability, DSRC has undergone extensive field testing worldwide, ensuring its practicality. IEEE 802.11bd, as the next-generation V2X (NGV) standard within DSRC, is expected to greatly exceed the performance of its predecessor, 802.11p. However, existing studies mention that the ambient traffic environment will influence the performance of V2X due to the cyber-physical properties of V2X. To fully assess the advancements of NGV, this study presents a comparative analysis of IEEE 802.11bd and IEEE 802.11p, focusing on dynamic traffic conditions. Specifically, the technical advancements of the IEEE 802.11bd standard are first theoretically examined, emphasizing significant enhancements in aspects like modulation and coding schemes, coding rates, and channel coding. Subsequently, these critical technical enhancements are implemented in Veins, a simulation framework for the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), encompassing large-scale dynamic traffic scenarios. The simulation results indicate that the IEEE 802.11bd standard significantly enhances the data transfer rate compared to IEEE 802.11p, achieving a stable twofold increase. Furthermore, the data transmission latency is reduced by over half compared to IEEE 802.11p, while the data transmission reliability experiences a noteworthy 20% enhancement. Notably, the enhanced data transmission mode of the IEEE 802.11bd standard requires an increased signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Additionally, this research evaluates the data dissemination properties in the IoV and finds that the traffic volume has a limited impact on the data propagation speed.
structured_info.methodology: Implemented key technical improvements (256-QAM MCS, 5/6 coding rate, LDPC coding) in the Veins simulation framework. Conducted comparative simulations in large-scale dynamic traffic scenarios (grid road and geometric road models) to evaluate data throughput and transmission reliability.
structured_info.conclusion: IEEE 802.11bd achieves approximately twice the data throughput and up to 20% higher transmission reliability than IEEE 802.11p in dynamic traffic scenarios. V2X standards and radio signal transmission power significantly improve data dissemination effectiveness, while traffic volume has limited impact on propagation distance.

analysis.Overview: Compares IEEE 802.11bd and IEEE 802.11p standards for V2X communication in dynamic traffic scenarios, focusing on data dissemination properties, throughput, and reliability enhancements using simulation-based evaluation.
Background_and_Motivation: Existing IEEE 802.11p struggles to meet increasing QoS demands (bandwidth, latency, reliability) for advanced vehicular applications.
Addresses research gaps in prior studies that oversimplified traffic scenarios and overlooked dynamic environmental impacts on IEEE 802.11bd performance.
Urgency is established through rapid ITS deployment and competition with C-V2X/NR-V2X standards, emphasizing DSRC's field-validated reliability advantage.
Links specific problem (inaccurate performance assessment) to broader challenge of standardizing next-generation V2X communication for safety-critical applications.
Contributes to transportation engineering, wireless communications, and cyber-physical systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: Enhanced Data Transmission Modes (64-QAM 5/6, 256-QAM 3/4, 256-QAM 5/6), LDPC Coding (replaces BCC), Midambles (channel estimation frames).
Logical relationships: New transmission modes enable higher data rates → require higher SNR; LDPC/midambles improve reliability → compensate for SNR limitations in dynamic environments.
Assumptions: AWGN channel model validity; traffic scenarios accurately represent real-world dynamics; simulation gains (1-4 dB SNR from LDPC) reflect physical improvements.
Contributes empirical validation of theoretical standards through novel large-scale simulations, advancing practical implementation knowledge.
Methodology: Hybrid approach: Theoretical analysis of IEEE 802.11bd enhancements followed by implementation in Veins IoV simulator. Simulated grid/geometric road scenarios with dynamic traffic flows.

Novelty: First to integrate 256-QAM and LDPC in Veins for large-scale traffic; applicability demonstrated via realistic scenarios; rationality ensured by referencing standard documents and prior SNR gain studies.
Data: Simulated vehicular trajectories from real-world models (Sioux Falls); preprocessing included OD demand calibration. Representativeness validated through traffic flow complexity.

Rigorous design: Multiple transmission modes tested; metrics include dissemination distance, packet reception count, SNR/PER relationships. Evaluation used statistical aggregation over randomized runs.
Follows cyber-physical systems paradigm, integrating communication physics with traffic dynamics to capture emergent V2X behaviors.
Results: 802.11bd achieves ~125% higher data rate and >56% lower latency than 802.11p. In simulations: 2× throughput (equivalent dissemination with doubled packet size), up to 20% reliability gain in simple scenarios (reduced to ~6% in complex ones). Traffic volume increases reception count proportionally but only ~10% dissemination distance gain.

Results are reliable (statistical validation via multiple runs) and stable across scenarios. Significance: Confirms 802.11bd's superiority while revealing diminishing returns for high-rate modes in complex environments.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structure: 1) Identify 802.11p limitations → 2) Present 802.11bd improvements → 3) Validate via simulation → 4) Compare performance → 5) Analyze dissemination properties.
Key steps: Theoretical MCS/LDPC analysis → Veins implementation → Scenario construction → Metric comparison → Sensitivity tests (traffic volume/power).

Strengths: Clear cause-effect (e.g., technical features → performance gains); weaknesses: Indirect simulation of physical effects (e.g., beamforming). Rebuttals addressed via SNR-gain adjustments and scenario diversity.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Novel large-scale simulation framework; first implementation of 802.11bd enhancements in Veins; empirical validation of dissemination properties (e.g., traffic volume's limited impact).
Methodology boundaries: Simplified channel model (AWGN); indirect implementation of physical layer gains; no NR-V2X comparison.
Theoretical paradigm (cyber-physical systems) emphasizes environmental interactions but may underrepresent MAC-layer innovations in conclusions.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions 802.11bd as DSRC's evolution against C-V2X, leveraging field-testing credibility. Terminology emphasizes 'reliability', 'throughput', 'dynamic scenarios'. Tone: Technical/assertive.
Builds authority through standards citations (IEEE 802.11bd/p) and simulation literature. Motivation: Advocate for 802.11bd's practicality amid standardization competition.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Conclusions: 802.11bd doubles throughput, improves reliability by up to 20%, and shows traffic volume minimally affects dissemination distance. Radio power optimization offers ~30% gains.
Future work: Explore 802.11bd mechanisms (e.g., repetition transmission); compare with NR-V2X; refine adaptive strategies for real-world deployment.
